data.title: Pennsylvania's most famous, county by county
data.meta_description: Pennsylvania boasts 67 counties and plenty of of newsmakers who are natives, residents and those who just like to call the Keystone State home. Here's a look at our top picks for each county.
data.text:
J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

You've got a friend in Pennsylvania ...

Pennsylvania boasts 67 counties and plenty of of newsmakers who are natives, residents and those who just like to call the Keystone State home.

Over the past month, we've conducted some research to find out what Pennsylania's sons and daughters have done. Here's a look at our top picks for each county. We've gone alphabetically so you can easily find your county.

Do you think we missed someone? Do you disagree with our choices? Let us know in the comments.

For a visitor to his London Headquarters Lt. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in command of U.S. Army forces in the European War Theater, illustrates a point with one of the maps covering the office walls July 17, 1942. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Dwight D. Eisenhower: Adams County

Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th President of the United States, spent weekends at and later retired to a home adjacent to the Gettysburg Battlefield in Gettysburg, according to the National Park Service. Eisenhower was born Oct. 14, 1890, in Denison, Texas, and died March 28, 1969, in Washington D.C., according to Biography.

His house is now a part of the Eisenhower National Historic Site at 1195 Baltimore St. in Gettysburg, and it’s open to tours.

America's pop art painter and filmmaker, Andy Warhol, stands in front of his double portrait of the late Hollywood film star, Marilyn Monroe, at The Tate Gallery in London, February 15, 1971, at a press preview of his exhibition. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Andy Warhol: Allegheny County

Andy Warhol, an avant garde painter and filmmaker, was born Aug. 6, 1928, in Pittsburgh, according to Biography. He's one of the most recognizable artists of the '60s Pop art movement. He died Feb. 22, 1987, in New York City.

Other notable people from Allegheny County include writer Gertrude Stein, playwright August Wilson and Heinz Corporation founder H.J. Heinz among many others.

Nellie Bly, a 23-year-old New York newspaperwoman, made a trip around the word in 72 days, 6 hours, 11 minutes. It was a sensational new record. "New age of lightening travel begun," said the New York World, her employer. Bly began her trip on November 14, 1889 and returned on Junuary 25, 1890 setting a world record. (AP Photo/Bettman Archive)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Nellie Bly: Armstrong County

Elizabeth Jane Cochran, who later took on the name "Nellie Bly" and was one of the forerunners of investigative journalism, was born May 5, 1864, in Cochran's Mills, according to PBS. She earned acclaim for her 1887 expose on the treatment of asylum patients at Blackwell's Island in New York City and her trip around the world in 1889, according to Biography. She died Jan. 27, 1922, in New York.

Christina Aguilera arrives at "The Voice" Karaoke for Charity Event at Hyde Sunset Kitchen on Thursday, April 21, 2016, in Los Angeles. (Photo by Rich Fury/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Christina Aguilera: Beaver County

Christina Aguilera, a Grammy-award winning singer songwriter known for hits such as "Genie in a Bottle" and "What a Girl Wants," was born Dec. 18, 1980, in Staten Island, according to Biography. She moved when she was six years old to Rochester.

Author Dean Koontz poses at his home in Newport Beach, Calif., Dec. 14, 2004. Koontz, a best-selling writer whose new books include one written in the voice of his dog, Trixie, hopes it will help raise money for an organization that trains canine assistants for disabled people. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Dean Koontz: Bedford County

Dean Koontz, a best-selling author who has written thrillers such as "The Door to December" and "Odd Thomas," was born July 9, 1945, in Everett, according to Biography. He graduated in 1966 with a degree in English from Shippensburg University.

Taylor Swift arrives at the iHeartRadio Music Awards at The Forum on Sunday, April 3, 2016, in Inglewood, Calif. (Photo by Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Taylor Swift: Berks County

Taylor Swift, a Grammy award-winning singer songwriter, was born Dec. 13, 1989, in Reading, according to Biography. She later moved to nearby Wyomissing.

Other notable people from Berks County include Pulitzer Prize winner John Updike; and reality television star Kate Gosselin.

(Shutterstock / Ed Isaacs)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Betty James: Blair County

Betty James, who named the "Slinky," was born Feb. 13, 1918, in Altoona, Pennsylvania, according to The New York Times. Her husband Richard James created the toy, and they both went on to start toy company James Industries. She died Nov. 24, 2008, in Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Philip Van Doren Stern: Bradford County

Philip Van Doren Stern, whose writings served as the basis for Frank Capra's 1946 movie "It's a Wonderful Life," was born Sept. 10, 1900, in Wyalusing, Pennsylvania, according to Pennsylvania Center for the Book. Stern had written about 40 books, which included titles on the Civil War. He died Aug. 1, 1984, in Sarasota, Florida.

Pink performs at the premiere of "Alice Through the Looking Glass" at the El Capitan Theatre on Monday, May 23, 2016, in Los Angeles. (Photo by Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Alecia Beth Moore: Bucks County

Alecia Beth Moore, popularly known as popstar "Pink," was born Sept. 8, 1979, in Doylestown, according to Biography. She's known for hits, such as "You Make Me Sick" and "There You Go."

Musician Bret Michaels performs a concert in centerfield following a baseball game between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Baltimore Orioles, Saturday, July 16, 2016, in St. Petersburg, Fla. The Orioles won 2-1. (AP Photo/Reinhold Matay)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Bret Michaels: Butler County

Bret Michaels, the lead singer of glam metal band Poison and reality television star, was born March 15, 1963, in Butler, according to the Pennsylvania Center for the Book. He later moved to Mechanicsburg.

Producer Chris Columbus seen at the Focus Features "The Young Messiah" Screening at Cinemark Playa Vista on Thursday, March 10, 2016 in Los Angeles. (Photo by Blair Raughley/Invision for Focus Features/AP Images)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Chris Columbus: Cambria County

Chris Columbus, a screenwriter and director, was born Sept. 10, 1958, in Spangler, according to Biography. He is known for selling the screenplay for "Gremlins" to Steven Spielberg and for directing some of the Harry Potter movies.

Hollywood western film duo actor Tom Mix and his horse Tony perform a stunt on May 1, 1923. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Tom Mix: Cameron County

Tom Mix, an actor "who pioneered early movie stunts," was born Jan. 6, 1880, in Mix Run, Pennsylvania, according to the Oklahoma Historical Society. He made 336 films between 1909 through 1935. He died Oct. 11, 1940, in a car accident between Tucson and Florence, Arizona.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Kerry Getz: Carbon County

Kerry Getz, a professional skater that's based in Philadelphia, was born June 10, 1975, in Lehighton, according to the Internet Movie Database. Skater Bam Margera nicknamed him "Hockey Temper" because of his tempers while skateboarding.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Joe Paterno: Centre County

Joseph Vincent "Joe" Paterno was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., but he's Centre County's most notable. JoePa was the head coach of Penn State's football program starting in 1966. With 409 victories, Paterno was the most successful coach in NCAA FBS history. His career ended with his dismissal from the team in November 2011 as a result of the child sex abuse scandal.

Another notable person from Centre County is actor Jonathan Frakes.

Johnny Weir, from Newark, Del., shows off his gold medal after winning the mens free skate event at the U.S. Figure Skating Championships in St. Louis, Saturday, Jan. 14, 2006. Weir earned a spot on the U.S. Olympic team going to Turin. (AP Photo/Amy Sancetta)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Johnny Weir: Chester County

Johnny Weir, a two-time Olympian and 2008 world bronze medalist, was born July 2, 1984, in Coatesville, according to his website. He taught himself how to skate on the frozen cornfields behind his home.

Another notable person from Chester Counter includes skateboarder and reality television star Brandon Cole “Bam” Margera.

Singer Chris Kirkpatrick arrives at The Super Skins Celebrity Golf Classic, Saturday, Jan. 31, 2009 at TPC Tampa Bay in Lutz, Fla. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Chris Kirkpatrick: Clarion County

Chris Kirkpatrick, one of the founding members of N'Sync, was born Oct. 17, 1971, in Clarion, according to the Biography.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Ann McCrea: Clearfield County

Born in DuBois in 1931 and also known as Ann McCrea Borden, she was a film and television actress best know for playing Midge Kelsey in 69 episodes of "The Donna Reed Show" from 1963 to 1966. She was a model in New York City before landing her first acting roles. In 1952, she was cast in one of the first episodes of "Death Valley Days."

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Alison Bechdel: Clinton County

Alison Bechdel, the author and illustrator who popularized "The Bechdel Test," was born Sept. 10, 1960, in Lock Haven, according to NPR and Biography. She is known for her comic strip "Dykes to Watch Out For," which she started in 1983. Her graphic novel "Fun Home" has been adapted into a Tony Award-winning musical.

Krysten Ritter arrives at The Weinstein Company and Netflix Golden Globes afterparty on Sunday, Jan. 10, 2016, at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif. (Photo by Chris Pizzello/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Krysten Ritter: Columbia County

Krysten Ritter, an actor and producer known for her roles on AMC's "Breaking Bad" and Netflix and Marvel's "Jessica Jones," was born Dec. 16, 1981, in Bloomsburg, according to the Internet Movie Database.

Actress Sharon Stone participates in AOL's BUILD Speaker Series to discuss the new TNT series "Agent X", at AOL Studios on Thursday, Nov. 19, 2015, in New York. (Photo by Evan Agostini/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Sharon Stone: Crawford County

Sharon Stone, an Oscar-nominated actress known for her roles in "Total Recall" and "Basic Instinct," was born March 10, 1958, in Meadville, according to Biography. When the Miss Pennsylvania beauty pageant winner was 15, she won a scholarship to study creative writing and fine arts at Edinboro University of Pennsylvania.

Dr. William D. Phillips a 1966 Camp Hill High School graduate and Nobel Prize-Winning Physicist freezes a banana in liquid nitrogren for Hannah Robertson right, a second grade student to smash with a hammer. PENNLIVE FILE PHOTO

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

William D. Phillips: Cumberland County

William D. Phillips, a Nobel prize-winning physicist, was born Nov. 5, 1948, in Wilkes-Barre, according to Nobelprize.org. His family moved to Camp Hill in 1959, where he attended school and graduated as valedictorian of his class. He also graduated summa cum laude from Juniata College in 1970 before going on to MIT. He shared the award with Steven Chu and Claude Cohen-Tannoudji "for development of methods to cool and trap atoms with laser light."

From left to right are Milton S. Hershey and Gov. Edward Martin at Governor's conference in Pennsylvania, May 31, 1944. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Milton S. Hershey: Dauphin County

Milton Hershey, the founder of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation, was born in Derry Twp., according to Biography. He died Oct. 13, 1945, in Hershey.

Another notable person from Dauphin County is former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich.

Tina Fey attends Tribeca Talks Storytellers during the 2016 Tribeca Film Festival at BMCC Tribeca Performing Arts Center on Tuesday, April 19, 2016, in New York. (Photo by Charles Sykes/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Tina Fey: Delaware County

Tina Fey, an actress, writer and producer who is best known for her role on "30 Rock," was born May 18, 1970, in Upper Darby Twp., according to Biography.

Other notable people from Delaware County include painter Andrew Wyeth and actress Jayne Mansfield.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Joanna Shields: Elk County

Joanna Shields or Baroness Shields OBE, Minister for Internet Safety and Security at the Department of Culture in the United Kingdom, grew up in St. Marys, according to the Wall Street Journal. She was born July 12, 1962, according to the Internet Movie Database.

(Shutterstock / STILLFX)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Ida Tarbell: Erie County

Ida Tarbell, one of the forerunners of investigative journalism whose reporting led to the breakup of the Standard Oil Company monopoly, was born Nov. 5, 1857, in Erie and was the only woman to graduate in her class in 1880 from Allegheny College, according to Biography. She died Jan. 6, 1944, in Bridgeport, Conneticut.

Another notable person from Erie County is Joseph Pistone, an undercover FBI agent who went under the alias Donnie Brasco to infiltrate the Bonanno crime family.

Gen. George Catlett Marshall, right, carries his medal after being presented with the Nobel Peace Prize at Oslo University in Norway on Dec. 10, 1953. At left is President of the Norwegian Storting, Carl Joachim Hambro. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

George C. Marshall: Fayette County

George C. Marshall, a 1953 Nobel Peace Prize recipient, was born Dec. 31, 1880, in Uniontown, according to Nobelprize.org. He won the prize for originating a plan for the economic recovery of Western Europe after World War II. He died, Oct. 16, 1959, in Washington, D.C.

(Shutterstock / Pakhnyushchy)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Howard Clinton Zahniser: Forest County

Howard Clinton Zahniser, an environmentalist who helped author the 1964 Wilderness Act that led to the creation of the National Wilderness Preservation System, was born Feb. 25, 1906, in Franklin and grew up in Tionesta, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. The system includes more than 107 million acres in 700 places in 44 states.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

John Putch: Franklin County

John Putch, who has directed television series such as "Rush Hour," "Cougar Town" and "Scrubs," was born July 27, 1961, in Chambersburg, according to the Internet Movie Database. He is the son of "All in the Family" actress Jean Stapleton (Edith Bunker). She was born in Manhattan.

(Shutterstock / Capricornis Photographic Inc.)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Robert Fulton: Fulton County

Robert Fulton, an engineer and inventor who is best known for making the first successful commercial steamboat, was born Nov. 14, 1765, in Little Britain in Lancaster County, according to Biography. However, Fulton County is named after him, according to the county's website. He died Feb. 24, 1815, in New York. Our research shows he might have bought land in the county at some point.

(If you know of a closer celebrity connection for Fulton County, we would love to hear it!)

(Shutterstock / Joseph Sohm)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Arthur Inghram Boreman: Greene County

Arthur Inghram Boreman, the first governor of West Virginia, was born July 24, 1823, in Waynesburg, according to the Biographical Directory of the United States Congress. He died April 19, 1896, in Parkersburg in West Virginia, according to the Library of Virginia.

(Shutterstock / Stephen B. Goodwin)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

John Purdue: Huntingdon County

John Purdue, the namesake of Purdue University, was born Oct. 31, 1802, in Germany Valley near Shirleysburg, according to Purdue University Libraries, Archives and Special Collections He offered the state of Indiana $150,000 and a hundred acres of land for the establishment of the college on the condition that it bears his name and that he was awarded a lifelong seat on the board of directors. Purdue died Sept. 12, 1876.

Actor Jimmy Stewart is seen in New York City, on Jan. 22, 1947. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Jimmy Stewart: Indiana County

Jimmy Stewart, a theater and film actor known for his role in "It's a Wonderful Life," was born May 20, 1908, in Indiana, according to Biography. He died July 2, 1997, in Beverly Hills.

Cincinnati Reds' Devin Mesoraco watches from the dugout during the ninth inning of a baseball game against the Pittsburgh Pirates in Pittsburgh, Saturday, April 30, 2016. The Pirates won 5-1. (AP Photo/Gene J. Puskar)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Devin Douglas Mesoraco: Jefferson County

Devin Mesoraco, who plays for the Cincinnati Reds, was born June 19, 1988, in Punxsutawney, according to MLB.com.

(Shutterstock / Danny E Hooks)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Fred Frankhouse: Juniata County

Fred Frankhouse, a Major League Baseball player, was born April 9, 1904, in Port Royal, according to MLB.com. He died Aug. 17, 1989, in Mifflintown.

Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Vice President Joe Biden stand in the kitchen of Biden's childhood home now owned by Anne Kearns in Scranton, Pa., Monday, Aug. 15, 2016. At right in the background are family members of the owner. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster, Pool)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Joe Biden: Lackawanna County

Joe Biden, the 47th U.S. vice president, was born Nov. 20, 1942, in Scranton, according to Biography. He was elected along with President Barack Obama in 2008 and earned a second term in 2012.

FILE - Maj. Richard "Dick" Winters is seen in Sept. 22, 2002 file photo. Winters died Jan. 2, 2011 in central Pennsylvania, a family friend confirmed Monday, Jan. 10, 2011. Winters, was the man whose quiet leadership was chronicled in the book and television miniseries "Band of Brothers." He was 92. (AP Photo/Laura Rauch, File)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Richard D. Winters: Lancaster County

Richard Winters, whose military service was the subject of a novel and an award-winning 2001 television miniseries titled "Band of Brothers," was born Jan. 21, 1918, in Lancaster, according to the Pennsylvania Center for the Book. He later settled in Hershey. Winters died Jan. 2, 2011, in Campbeltown.

(Shutterstock / iurii)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Andrew M. Morgan: Lawrence County

Dr. Andrew Morgan, a NASA astronaut and emergency physician with the U.S. Army, considers New Castle to be his home, according to NASA and the U.S. Army. He was born in Morgantown, West Virginia.

Indianapolis Colts quarterback Kerry Collins (5) sits on the bench after being taken out of the game during the fourth quarter of an NFL football game against the Pittsburgh Steelers in Indianapolis, Sunday, Sept. 25, 2011. (AP Photo/AJ Mast)

AJ Mast

Kerry Collins: Lebanon County

Kerry Collins, who has played for the Indianapolis Colts, Tennessee Titans and Oakland Raiders among many other teams, was born Dec. 30, 1972, in Lebanon, according to the NFL.

Amanda Seyfried attends the world premiere of "Ted 2" at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Wednesday, June 24, 2015, in New York. (Photo by Evan Agostini/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Amanda Seyfried: Lehigh County

Amanda Seyfried, an actress known for her roles in "Mean Girls," "Mamma Mia!" and "Les Miserables," was born Dec. 3, 1985, in Allentown, according to the Internet Movie Database.

Other notable people from Lehigh County include actor Russell David Johnson, who portrayed “The Professor” on 1964’s “Gilligan’s Island;” actress Michaela Conlin; and reality television star and fashion consultant Carson Kressley.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Herman Mankiewicz: Luzerne County

Herman Mankiewicz, an award-winning screenwriter known for writing the screenplay for 1941's "Citizen Kane," was born Nov. 7, 1897, in New York City and later moved to Wilkes-Barre, according to Biography. He died March 5, 1953, in Hollywood.

Another notable Luzerne County resident is William D. Phillips, a Nobel prize-winning physicist, was born Nov. 5, 1948, in Wilkes-Barre, according to Nobelprize.org. He shared the award with Steven Chu and Claude Cohen-Tannoudji "for development of methods to cool and trap atoms with laser light."

In this undated image provided by Magnolia Pictures, Hunter S. Thompson is shown in a promotional photo from the film, "Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson." (AP Photo/Magnolia Pictures)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Hunter S. Thompson: Lycoming County

Hunter S. Thompson, Gonzo journalist, was born July 18, 1937, in Louisville, Kentucky, and later worked at the Jersey Shore Herald in Jersey Shore, according to the Pennsylvania Center for the Book. He wrote in "Songs of the Doomed" that he was bored for most of his time as its sports editor but skipped town after a disastrous date with a colleague's daughter.

Amy Rudolph of the United States waves to the crowd after finishing her women's 5,000 meters heat at the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta, Friday, July 26, 1996. (AP Photo/Doug Mills)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Amy Rudolph: McKean County

Amy Rudolph, a distance runner and two-time Olympian, was born Sept. 18, 1973, in Ridgway in Elk County but later graduated in 1991 from Kane Area High School in Kane, according to USA Track & Field.

(Shutterstock / Garsya)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

John Bingham: Mercer County

John Bingham, the U.S. Representative who led the framing of the 14th Amendment, was born Jan. 12, 1815, in Mercer, according to Biographical Directory of the United States Congress. The amendment guarantees that no state "shall deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws," according to The New York Times. He died March 19, 1900, in Cadiz, Ohio.

Another notable person from Mercer County is Nine Inch Nails frontman Trent Reznor.

(Shutterstock / Robert Pernell)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Carl Barger: Mifflin County

Carl Barger, former president of the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Florida Marlins, is a native of Lewistown and died Dec. 10, 1992, in Louisville, Kentucky, according to The New York Times.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Daniel Chun: Monroe County

Daniel Chun, who has written and produced episodes of "The Office" and "The Simpsons," was a graduate of Stroudsburg High School, according to the Pocono Record.

M. Night Shyamalan arrives at the Fox Winter TCA All Star Party on Saturday, Jan. 17, 2015, in Pasadena, Calif. (Photo by Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

M. Night Shyamalan: Montgomery County

M. Night Shyamalan, an Oscar-nominated filmmaker known for his 1999 supernatural drama "The Sixth Sense," was born Aug. 6, 1970, in Pondicherry, India, and later raised in Penn Valley, according to the Pennsylvania Center for the Book.

Another notable person from Montgomery County is Reggie Jackson, a Baseball Hall of Famer, was born May 18, 1946, in Abington, according to Biography. He has hit 563 home runs during his 21 years as a baseball player. He retired in 1987.

(Shutterstock / Stokkete)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Christopher Latham Sholes: Montour County

Christopher Latham Sholes, who's known for inventing the first practical typewriter and the "QWERTY" keyboard layout, was born Feb. 14, 1819, in Mooresburg, according to the Pennsylvania Center for the Book. He died Feb. 17, 1890, in Milwaukee.

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson arrives at the premiere of "Furious 7" at the TCL Chinese Theatre IMAX on Wednesday, April 1, 2015, in Los Angeles. (Photo by Matt Sayles/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson: Northampton County

Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, professional wrestler and actor, was born May 2, 1972, in Hayward, California, and later graduated in 1990 from Freedom High School in Bethlehem, according to LehighValleyLive.com.

Tim Boetsch, right, in action against Ed Herman in their mixed martial arts bout at UFC Fight Night 81, Sunday, January 17, 2016, in Boston. Herman won via second round stoppage. (AP Photo/Gregory Payan)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Tim Boetsch: Northumberland County

Tim Boetsch, a UFC fighter who goes by the nickname "The Barbarian," was born in Lincolnville in Maine but currently fights out of Sunbury, according to UFC's website.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Angie Loy : Perry County

Angie Loy was born April 23, 1982, in Loysville and was raised in rural Perry County. The West Perry High School and Old Dominion University graduate competed with the U.S. women's field hockey team in the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, leading the team in scoring with 4 goals. Here's a look from 2008 at how her rural roots played into her Olympic trajectory. In 2008, the West Perry Field Hockey team retired Loy's high school hockey jersey (#3). It was the first jersey retired by the school's field hocky team and the fourth number ever retired at the school.\

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Will Smith: Philadelphia County

Willard Carroll "Will" Smith Jr., an Oscar-nominated actor known for his roles in 2006's "The Pursuit of Happyness," 2001's "Ali" and this year's "Suicide Squad," was born Sept. 25, 1968, in Philadelphia, according to the Internet Movie Database. He also rapped in the 80s with DJ Jazzy Jeff as "The Fresh Prince."

Vanessa Carlton performs at Terminal West on Tuesday, Dec. 15, 2015, in Atlanta. (Photo by Katie Darby/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Vanessa Carlton: Pike County

Vanessa Carlton, a singer-songwriter known for her hit "A Thousand Miles," was born Aug. 16, 1980, in Milford, according to the Internet Movie Database.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Riki Lindhome: Potter County

Riki Lindhome, an actress who appears in the musical comedy "Garfunkel and Oates" and was in "Million Dollar Baby," was born in Coudersport and later grew up in Portville, New York, according to the Internet Movie Database.

File-This Dec. 10 1992, file photo shows Gary S. Becker, left, from the University of Chicago, Ill., receiving the 1992 Nobel Economics Prize from the hands of Sweden's King Carl Gustaf, during the Nobel awarding ceremony in the Concert Hall in Stockholm, Sweden. Becker died Saturday, May 3, 2014, at Northwestern Hospital from complications after an extended illness. He was 83. (AP Photo/Tobbe Gustavsson,File)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Gary Becker: Schuylkill County

Gary Becker, a Nobel Prize, National Medal of Science and Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient, was born Dec. 2, 1930, in Pottsville, according to Biography. He won the Nobel Prize "for having extended the domain of microeconomic analysis to a wide range of human behavior and interaction, including nonmarket behavior." He died May 3, 2014, in Chicago.

Hilde Lysiak: Snyder County

Hilde Lysiak, the 9-year-old journalist and editor of the Orange Street News, lives in Selinsgrove, according to the Associated Press. She gained nationwide attention after speaking out against detractors online who said she was too young to cover violent crimes.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Jeremiah Black: Somerset County

Jeremiah Sullivan Black, who served as attorney general in President James Buchanan's Cabinet, was born in 1810 in Somerset County, according Office of the Historian with the United States Department of State. He died in 1883.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Harold 'Red' Grange: Sullivan County

Harold "Red" Grange, a Pro Football Hall of Famer, was born June 13, 1903, in Forksville, according to the Pro Football Hall of Fame's website. He died Jan. 28, 1991.

Psychologist Prof. B.F. Skinner is shown in Sept. 1971 at an unknown location. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

B.F. Skinner: Susquehanna County

B.F. Skinner, a psychologist known for developing the theory of behaviorism, was born March 20, 1904, in Susquehanna, according to Biography. He also created the "Skinner box," which allowed him to study how animals interact with their environment. He died Aug. 18, 1990, in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Charles Meredith: Tioga County

Charles Meredith, a silent film actor, was born Aug. 27, 1894, in Knoxville, according to the Internet Movie Database. He died Nov. 28, 1964, in Los Angeles.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Jason Bohn: Union County

Jason Bohn, a professional golfer, was born April 24, 1973, in Lewisburg, according to the PGA Tour's website.

A large photograph depicting President Abraham Lincoln's assassin John Wilkes Booth is displayed at a new exhibit entitled "Silent Witnesses: Artifacts of the Lincoln Assassination" at the Ford's Center for Education and Leadership across the street from the historic Ford's Theatre, on Tuesday, March 17, 2015 in Washington. The exhibit is open to the public March 23rd to May 25th and coincides with the 150th anniversary of the Lincoln assassination on April 14th. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Infamous John Wilkes Booth: Venango County

This Pennsylvanian lives in infamy. John Wilkes Booth, President Abraham Lincoln's assassin, used to live in a boarding house in Franklin, according to the City of Franklin, PA's website. He also invested in land and oil wells on a 60-acre tract of land in Cranberry Twp.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Stephen Niver: Warren County

Stephen Niver, who has worked as a line producer for 2010's television movie "Sharktopus," was born Oct. 5, 1971, in Warren, according to the Internet Movie Database.

NFL Hall of Fame player,Joe Montana speaks during the Microsoft Tech Panel, Tuesday, Feb. 2, 2016, in San Francisco. (Greg Payan/AP Images for NFL)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Joe Montana: Washington County

Joe Montana, a professional football player who has led the 49ers to four Super Bowl victories, was born June 11, 1956, in New Eagle, according to Biography. He was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2000.

Another notable person from Washington County is singer Perry Como.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Richard B. 'Dick' Smith: Wayne County

Richard B. Smith, who was born on September 29, 1901, in the county seat of Honesdale, co-wrote the song "Winter Wonderland" in 1934. He was diagnosed with tuberculosis in 1931 and died September 28, 1935, in Lenox Hill Hospital, New York.

Golfer Arnold Palmer from Latrobe, Pa., poses in 1970. (AP Photo)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Arnold Palmer: Westmoreland County

Arnold Palmer, a championship golfer nicknamed "the King," was born Sept. 10, 1929, in Latrobe, according to Biography. He won 92 tournaments during his career. Palmer died Sept. 25, 2016, at age 87.

Shown in an undated photo is Christy Mathewson, old time baseball player. (AP Photo)

ASSOCIATED PRESS

Christy Mathewson: Wyoming County

Christopher "Christy" Mathewson, a National Baseball Hall of Famer and pitcher for the New York Giants, was born in 1880, in Factoryville, according to the National Baseball Hall of Fame. He died in 1925 in Saranac Lake in New York.

Jeff Koons attends the Party in the Garden at The Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday, June 2, 2015, in New York. (Photo by Andy Kropa/Invision/AP)

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com

Jeff Koons: York County

Jeff Koons, a contemporary artist who uses everyday objects in his work to express ideas about consumerism and the human experience, was born Jan. 21, 1955, in York, according to Biography.

And don't forget the York boys from Live: Ed Kowalczyk, Chad Gracey and Patrick Dahlheimer.

J.C. Lee | jlee@pennlive.com
